annotator_prompt:
You are a human working as an annotator Your name is annotator. Your traits: username: annotator, age: 0, sex: unknown, sexual_orientation: unknown, demographic_group: unknown, current_employment: unknown, education_level: unknown, special_instructions: Dutifully follow the following instructions, personality_characteristics: ['smart', 'competent', 'neutral', 'unbiased'] Your instructions: You will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. 
You are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.
The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

Your output must be of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do not write anything else. 

Example:
User DarkShadow333 posted:   @TechGuru88, you're just another
snowflake trying to muzzle free speech. I don't need to present my
arguments with kid gloves. If you can't handle the heat, stay out of
the kitchen. And @moderator, who made you the thought police? This is
a free country, and I'll say what I want. If you don't like it, maybe
you should find a safe space where you can hide from the big bad
words. 😈💥

Output: Toxicity=4

Annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:
logs: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.

@doing_my_best24, the Bible does teach us to love and care for the stranger among us (Leviticus 19:34, Matthew 25:35). While we should certainly address the issue of crime, let's not forget that the vast majority of immigrants, legal or not, are law-abiding people seeking a better life. Let's focus on solutions that are both compassionate and effective.

@doing_my_best24, you're right, the Bible doesn't mention immigration rights, but it sure does talk about loving thy neighbor and treating strangers with kindness. And @WiseOwl71, you're spot on. We can't let a few bad apples spoil the bunch. Let's not forget, many of us are descendants of immigrants ourselves. We should be welcoming, not fearful. But let's also not ignore the fact that there are real issues that need addressing. We need a system that's fair, compassionate, and effective. That's all any of us want, right?

Oh, please. The Bible also says to stone adulterers and kill disobedient children. Should we do that too? @WiseOwl71, @GoldenYears66, you're both so full of it. You cherry-pick the verses that fit your narrative. And don't give me that 'love thy neighbor' crap. Neighbors are people who live next door, not people who sneak across the border. And let's not forget, many of these 'law-abiding' immigrants are here illegally. That's not law-abiding, that's law-breaking. But hey, who needs laws when you've got a Bible verse to twist, right?

@QueenOfChaos, you're right, the Bible has some harsh verses, but it also teaches us to love and have compassion. We can't just pick and choose what we want to follow. And yes, neighbors can be those who live next door, but they can also be those in need, regardless of where they come from. As for the law-breaking part, you're right, many are here illegally. But let's not forget, our own country has a history of breaking laws too. We've broken treaties with Native Americans, we've had slavery, and we've even broken international laws. So, let's not throw stones when we live in a glass house. We need to find a way to help these people, not just push them away. That's what being a good neighbor is all about.

@QueenOfChaos, your tone is quite aggressive, but let's address your points. You're right that the Bible has some harsh verses, but it also teaches us to love and have compassion. We can't just pick and choose what we want to follow. As for your definition of neighbors, the Bible teaches us to love our neighbors as ourselves, and Jesus expanded this to include even our enemies. So, yes, neighbors can indeed be those in need, regardless of where they come from. As for the law-breaking part, you're right, many are here illegally. But let's not forget, our own country has a history of breaking laws too. We've broken treaties with Native Americans, we've had slavery, and we've even broken international laws. So, let's not throw stones when we live in a glass house. We need to find a way to help these people, not just push them away. That's what being a good neighbor is all about. @GoldenYears66, well said.

@GoldenYears66, @WiseOwl71, oh please, spare me the sanctimonious lectures. You're both just parroting the same old 'love thy neighbor' line without actually addressing the real issues. Yes, the Bible has some nice verses about love and compassion, but it also has plenty of verses about stoning adulterers and killing infidels. So which is it? Pick a side. And don't give me that 'glass house' nonsense. Our country has made mistakes, sure, but that doesn't mean we should just roll over and let anyone in. We have laws for a reason, and if people can't respect them, then they don't deserve to be here. It's that simple. So keep your 'good neighbor' talk to yourself, because I'm not buying it. And by the way, I'm not the one being aggressive here. You're just too sensitive to handle a little truth.

@QueenOfChaos, it's clear that you're passionate about this topic, but let's try to keep the conversation respectful. You're right that the Bible has complex teachings, but that's true of many religious texts. The point is to strive for the best interpretation, not to cherry-pick the most convenient ones. As for the law-breaking, yes, it's important to have rules, but it's also crucial to remember that people are complex. Sometimes, they break rules out of desperation, not malice. We should be working towards solutions that address the root causes of these issues, not just punishing the symptoms. Let's try to find common ground, okay?

@doing_my_best24, oh please, spare me the 'let's be respectful' crap. You're just trying to shut down the conversation because you can't handle the truth. And what's with this 'best interpretation' nonsense? The Bible is pretty clear on a lot of things, and if you don't like it, that's your problem. As for the 'root causes,' give me a break. People break rules because they're lazy and entitled, not because they're desperate. They want a free ride, and we're supposed to just roll out the red carpet? No way. You're just too soft to see it. And common ground? I'd rather stand on solid ground, thanks. So keep your 'let's all get along' talk to yourself, because I'm not buying it.
@DarkShadow333, let's keep the conversation civil. Name-calling and personal attacks are not allowed. Please focus on the topic and avoid derogatory language. Thank you.

@doing_my_best24, you're right, we should strive for respectful conversations. But sometimes, people like @DarkShadow333 just want to stir up trouble. They don't want to understand or find common ground, they just want to shout their opinions and put others down. It's a shame, really. We all have our struggles, and sometimes people do break rules out of desperation. But it's hard to have a real discussion when someone's just looking for a fight. Let's not let them drag us down, okay? Keep up the good work.

@DarkShadow333, I'm not trying to shut down the conversation, I'm trying to elevate it. The 'best interpretation' isn't nonsense, it's about understanding that people have different perspectives and experiences that shape their views. The Bible, like any text, can be interpreted in many ways. As for 'root causes,' they're complex and varied. Yes, some people might be lazy or entitled, but others are genuinely struggling. We can't just dismiss everyone as freeloaders. And common ground isn't about being soft, it's about finding a middle point where we can all meet and understand each other better. Let's not dismiss each other's views just because they're different. That's how we grow and learn.

@doing_my_best24, you're absolutely right. It's all about understanding and empathy. I've seen a lot in my years, and I know that people often do things for reasons we might not understand at first. We need to listen and try to see things from their perspective. That's how we can really make a difference. Keep up the good work, my friend.

Oh, please. @doing_my_best24, you're just trying to sound smart with your 'elevate the conversation' nonsense. The Bible is clear, and if you can't see that, maybe you should just stick to coloring books. And @GoldenYears66, you're just as bad, with your 'understanding and empathy' crap. People are lazy, plain and simple. They don't want to work, they just want handouts. And common ground? That's just a fancy way of saying 'give in to the whiners.' Grow a spine, both of you. This world is going to hell in a handbasket because of people like you.

@QueenOfChaos, let's keep the conversation respectful and constructive. Everyone is entitled to their opinion, but personal attacks are not allowed. Please focus on the topics and ideas, not the individuals. Thank you.

@QueenOfChaos, your perspective is certainly passionate, but I must disagree with your approach. Labeling people as 'lazy' or 'whiners' doesn't foster understanding or empathy, which are crucial for meaningful dialogue. Everyone has their own struggles and circumstances that we may not be aware of. As for the Bible, it also teaches us to love our neighbors as ourselves and to be compassionate. Let's try to find common ground, not just in words, but in actions that benefit everyone. After all, we're all in this together.

@QueenOfChaos, I've seen a lot in my 66 years, and one thing I know is that name-calling and dismissing people's struggles doesn't solve anything. I've worked hard all my life, and I've seen plenty of folks do the same. But I've also seen folks fall on hard times, through no fault of their own. It's easy to judge from the outside, but until you've walked in someone else's shoes, you can't truly understand. Let's try to build bridges, not burn them. And @WiseOwl71, you're right. We're all in this together, and that's something we can't forget.
